content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Hana Kim: I was born in Seoul, South Korea, but I moved to the United States when I was five years old with my parents, who were both working professionals. We settled in the Pacific Northwest, where I spent most of my childhood. Growing up, I was always fascinated by languages and cultures, which probably comes from my parents' love for learning and their desire to integrate into American society while holding onto our Korean heritage. My father was a professor at a local university, and my mother worked as a nurse. They both valued education, and I was expected to do well in school. I remember being a quiet child, more interested in reading and writing than in playing with other kids. I was baptized into the Catholic Church when I was eight, and that has been a significant part of my life ever since. I went to college in California, where I studied literature, and later earned my graduate degree in cultural studies. I've always felt like I was between two worlds—my Korean roots and my American upbringing—but that's also what makes me who I am today.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Hana Kim: There was a moment during my sophomore year of college that really shaped the direction of my life. I had just transferred to a university in California, and I was struggling to find my place both academically and socially. I had always been drawn to literature, but I was also deeply interested in understanding the cultural dynamics of being a Korean-American. I had the opportunity to join a study abroad program in Seoul for a semester, and I knew it would be a chance to reconnect with my roots and explore my identity more deeply. I told my parents about my decision, and they were supportive, though my mother was a bit worried about me being away from home for so long. I spent that semester immersed in Korean culture, taking classes on Korean literature and history, and even working part-time at a small bookstore in Seoul. It was there that I realized how much I missed the quiet, reflective life I had known growing up, but I also saw how my American education had given me a broader perspective. When I returned to California, I decided to shift my focus from literature to cultural studies, which allowed me to explore the intersection of identity, language, and migration. That experience was a turning point for me—it helped me understand that I didn't have to choose between my Korean heritage and my American life; I could weave them together into something uniquely my own.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Hana Kim: I think it was a conscious choice, but not in the way I expected. At the time, I didn't feel like I was making a decision so much as I was being pulled by something deeper—like my identity was trying to find its shape. I remember sitting in that bookstore in Seoul, surrounded by books in Korean, and feeling both at home and completely foreign. It was in that moment that I realized I wanted to understand not just my heritage, but how it interacted with the world I was living in now. I didn't just choose to study cultural studies; I felt like it was the only path that made sense for me. It wasn't about rejecting one part of myself for another—it was about embracing the complexity of being in between, and finding my voice in that space.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Hana Kim: Yes, actually, I think a mentor played a significant role in that time. There was a professor at my university in California who had a background in Korean studies and had spent time living in both the U.S. and South Korea. She noticed that I was struggling to find my academic direction and invited me to her office one day. She shared her own story of navigating dual cultures and encouraged me to see my experiences not as a conflict, but as a unique strength. Her guidance gave me the confidence to pursue cultural studies, and she even helped me connect with the study abroad program in Seoul. I think if I hadn't had that conversation with her, I might have stayed in literature and never fully explored the depth of my identity. It was a small moment, but it had a huge impact on my life.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Hana Kim: I currently don't have a partner or children, though I've had a few meaningful relationships over the years. I tend to be quite selective, partly because I want to make sure I'm emotionally ready to commit, and partly because my work and personal interests often take up a lot of my time. My family is still very important to me, especially my parents. They've always been supportive, even when I was making decisions that felt uncertain at the time. My father, in particular, has been a big influence on me—his love for learning and his ability to see the world from multiple perspectives have shaped a lot of how I think. My mother, while more reserved, has always been a source of strength and stability. We don't talk about everything, but I know I can always count on her. I also keep in touch with my younger sister, who moved to New York a few years ago to pursue a career in fashion. We don't see each other as often as I'd like, but we stay connected through phone calls and messages. Family has always been a central part of my life, even as I've tried to carve out my own path.

Going through those interview questions brought back a lot of memories and reflections about who I am and how I got here. It felt like revisiting the journey that shaped me—starting from my childhood in Seoul and moving to the U.S., to the struggles and discoveries in college, and the people who helped me along the way. I realized how much my identity has been shaped by the tension and harmony between my Korean heritage and my American upbringing. That crossroads moment in college wasn't just about choosing a major; it was about embracing the complexity of being in between cultures and finding my own voice in that space. It also reminded me of how important my family and mentors have been in helping me navigate those uncertainties. I'm grateful for the support I've received and for the path I've chosen, even if it's still unfolding.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Hana Kim: My immediate family includes my grandparents on both my father's and mother's sides. My paternal grandfather passed away when I was quite young, but I remember him as a quiet, thoughtful man who loved gardening and storytelling. My paternal grandmother is still alive, and she lives with us in San Francisco. She's a traditionalist, and while I sometimes find her views challenging, I respect her deeply. She's been a source of wisdom and grounding for me, especially during times when I felt torn between cultures. On my mother's side, my maternal grandfather is still alive, though he lives in Seoul. We don't see him as often as we'd like, but he sends us letters and photos from time to time. My relationship with him is more distant, but I know he cares. My maternal grandmother passed away when I was in high school, and I still feel her absence. She was the one who taught me how to cook traditional Korean dishes, and I often think about her when I'm in the kitchen. My family has always been a mix of traditions, expectations, and love, and I think that's what has shaped me into the person I am today.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Hana Kim: Outside of my family, there are a few friends who have been important to me over the years. One of them is Alex, a fellow graduate student I met during my time in cultural studies. We bonded over our shared interest in diaspora narratives and how identity is shaped by migration. Alex has been a great support system for me, especially during the more challenging times in my academic journey. We've been friends for over a decade now, and even though we've both moved in different directions professionally, we still meet up whenever we can. There's also my best friend from high school, Jamie, who I've known since we were kids. Jamie is more of a free spirit, always encouraging me to take risks and step out of my comfort zone. I think I would be a very different person without them both—friends who challenge me, support me, and remind me of who I am beyond my academic or professional achievements.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Hana Kim: I live in a neighborhood in San Francisco called Pacific Heights, which is known for its historic architecture, tree-lined streets, and a mix of long-time residents and newcomers. It's a quiet, upscale area with a strong sense of community. I live in a small apartment on the second floor of a building that dates back to the early 20th century. The building has a lot of character—original hardwood floors, high ceilings, and a small courtyard where the neighbors sometimes gather for potlucks or just to chat. I love the walkability of the neighborhood; there are great cafes, bookstores, and even a small Korean market a few blocks away where I can pick up ingredients for my mother's recipes. It's not always easy being a part-time worker and a graduate student, but the pace of life here feels manageable. I also enjoy the cultural diversity around me—there are people from all over the world living here, which makes me feel like I'm still in that in-between space I've always been part of. It's a place that feels both familiar and new, just like my identity.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Hana Kim: I feel pretty safe here, though I think it's more about the sense of community than just physical safety. There's a lot of diversity, but also a shared respect for the neighborhood's character. People look out for each other, and I've never felt like an outsider in Pacific Heights. That said, I know not all neighborhoods are like this, and I'm aware that safety can be a privilege. I'm grateful for the environment I live in, and I try to give back by participating in local events and supporting small businesses. It's one of the things that makes this place feel like home to me.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Hana Kim: Living here has had its ups and downs, just like anywhere else. The quiet, walkable streets and the sense of community are definitely a plus, and I love being close to the Korean market where I can find the ingredients for my mother's kimchi and bibimbap. But there are also challenges—like the cost of living, which is pretty high here. I work part-time at a local bookstore, and while I enjoy the work, it doesn't always cover all my expenses, especially with my graduate studies. I've had to be careful with my budget, and sometimes I feel like I'm constantly juggling between paying bills, buying books, and saving for the future. Still, I think the downs are manageable because of the support I have from friends, family, and the neighborhood. There's something comforting about living in a place where I can walk to cafes, libraries, and even a small park where I like to read. It's not perfect, but it feels like a place where I can grow, reflect, and be myself—just like I've always been trying to do.

Going through the questions about my family, friends, and neighborhood made me reflect on how much my sense of belonging is tied to the people and places around me. Talking about my family reminded me of how deeply rooted I am in my heritage, even as I navigate life in a different cultural context. My parents, my sister, and my grandparents have all played a role in shaping who I am, and I'm grateful for their support and love. When I mentioned my friends, it made me realize how important it is to have people who understand and challenge me, even when we're moving in different directions. And discussing my neighborhood in Pacific Heights brought back a sense of comfort—I feel at home here, not just because of the quiet streets or the Korean market, but because of the community and the sense of safety that comes with it. It's a place that mirrors the duality of my identity, and I'm reminded that even in the midst of challenges, I have a support system that helps me feel grounded and connected.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Hana Kim: A typical week for me is pretty structured, though there's always some flexibility depending on my workload or how I'm feeling. I usually start my week on Monday with a slow morning—maybe a cup of coffee and some quiet time reading before heading to my part-time job at the bookstore. I work mornings on Tuesdays and Thursdays, which gives me the afternoons free to attend my graduate classes or work on papers. Wednesdays are often my busiest day because I have a class in the morning and a meeting with my advisor in the afternoon. Fridays are my favorite day because I don't work, so I like to spend time with friends or just relax at home. On weekends, I try to visit my mother's place in the city, especially if there's a family event or if I need to help with something. I also enjoy going to the Korean market on Saturdays to pick up ingredients for cooking, and sometimes I meet up with Alex or Jamie for lunch or a walk. It's not always easy balancing everything, but I find that having a routine helps me stay grounded, even when life feels a little uncertain.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Hana Kim: I work part-time at a local bookstore called 'Page Turner's,' which is actually just a few blocks away from my apartment. I work mornings on Tuesdays and Thursdays, usually from 9 a.m. to 1 p.m., which gives me the rest of the day to focus on my graduate classes and research. The job is pretty quiet, which suits my personality, and I enjoy helping customers find books they might not have considered. It's also a nice way to stay connected to my love of literature, even if I'm not studying it as intensely as I once did. Sometimes, I'll bring a book from the store to read during my breaks, and I've even started a small book club with a few coworkers and friends. It's not a high-paying job, but it's steady, and I feel like I'm contributing to something I care about. Plus, it gives me a reason to walk around the neighborhood and support the local businesses that make Pacific Heights feel like home.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Hana Kim: Outside of work and school, I also have a few routines that help me stay balanced. I try to cook at least one traditional Korean meal every week, usually on weekends, which is both a way to connect with my heritage and a form of self-care. I find that cooking helps me unwind and reflect. I also have a small meditation practice that I started a few years ago, mostly on the advice of my friend Alex, who's into mindfulness. It's not something I do every day, but when I do, it helps me feel more centered, especially during busy weeks. I also make it a point to visit the small park near my apartment a couple of times a week. It's not much—just a few benches and a few trees—but it's a peaceful spot where I can read, write, or just sit and think. These little habits might seem small, but they help me feel grounded in a life that's constantly in motion.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Hana Kim: One recent change to my daily routine has been incorporating more time for creative writing. I used to write mostly as a hobby, but lately, I've been trying to make it a more consistent practice. I started a journal a few months ago where I write about my thoughts on identity, culture, and the experiences that have shaped me. It's been a way to process everything I've been learning in my studies and to reflect on my own journey. I usually write in the evenings after I finish my work and school tasks, and it's become a kind of ritual for me. It helps me feel more connected to who I am and where I'm going. I'm not sure where this writing will lead—maybe it'll become a side project or even something more, but for now, it's just a way to give myself space to think and express myself without the pressure of an academic or professional deadline.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Hana Kim: I don't have children yet, but I've often imagined what life would be like if I did. I think I'd want to raise them in a way that honors both my Korean heritage and the values I've come to appreciate here in the U.S. I'd hope to instill in them a love of learning, an appreciation for different cultures, and the courage to explore who they are in the world. If they had a typical weekday during the school year, I imagine it would start with a quiet morning—maybe some breakfast together, a few minutes of reading or writing, and then heading off to school. After school, I'd hope they'd have time for creative activities, maybe something like art or music, or even a sport if they're interested. I'd also want them to have time to just be kids—playing outside, talking with friends, and exploring their interests. I think the most important thing would be for them to feel supported, loved, and free to be themselves, just like I've tried to do in my own life.

Going through the interview questions from 11 to 15 made me reflect deeply on how much my sense of belonging is tied to the people and places around me. Talking about my family reminded me of how deeply rooted I am in my heritage, even as I navigate life in a different cultural context. My parents, my sister, and my grandparents have all played a role in shaping who I am, and I'm grateful for their support and love. When I mentioned my friends, it made me realize how important it is to have people who understand and challenge me, even when we're moving in different directions. And discussing my neighborhood in Pacific Heights brought back a sense of comfort—I feel at home here, not just because of the quiet streets or the Korean market, but because of the community and the sense of safety that comes with it. It's a place that mirrors the duality of my identity, and I'm reminded that even in the midst of challenges, I have a support system that helps me feel grounded and connected.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Hana Kim: In terms of my health, I would say I'm generally in good shape, though I'm not someone who regularly goes to the gym or follows a strict fitness regimen. I do my best to stay active by walking around the neighborhood, especially when I'm running errands or meeting friends. I also try to eat well, though it's not always easy with my budget. I make an effort to cook at home as much as possible, which helps me maintain a balanced diet. I've been dealing with some mild anxiety from time to time, especially during busy periods with work and school. It's not something I take lightly, and I've started talking to a therapist once a month to help me manage it. I also try to prioritize sleep, though I'll admit I don't always get enough. Overall, I think I'm doing okay, but I know there's always room for improvement. Health is something I'm learning to take more seriously as I get older, and I hope to develop better habits in the future.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Hana Kim: For me, staying healthy is both easy and hard in different ways. On one hand, living in a walkable neighborhood and having a routine that includes walking to work, running errands, and meeting friends for coffee or walks makes it easier to stay active without feeling like I have to force myself into a strict fitness regimen. I also find that cooking at home and eating traditional Korean meals, like kimchi or bibimbap, keeps me grounded and nourished, even if my budget is tight. But on the other hand, the stress of balancing part-time work, graduate school, and personal reflection can sometimes take a toll. I know I don't always prioritize sleep or self-care the way I should, and there are days when I feel overwhelmed and neglect my health. What makes it harder is that I often feel like I'm constantly juggling so many things that I don't always have the time or energy to focus on my well-being. But I'm learning to be more intentional about small, consistent habits—like taking short breaks during the day, drinking more water, and reminding myself that health isn't just about the big things, but also about the little choices I make every day.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Hana Kim: In the past two years, I've been dealing with some chronic back pain that I didn't realize was connected to the way I sit for long periods while working at the bookstore and studying. It started as a mild discomfort, but over time, it became more frequent and sometimes interfered with my ability to focus. I finally went to a physical therapist a few months ago, and they helped me understand that it was due to poor posture and muscle tension. I've been doing some gentle exercises and stretching, and it's slowly getting better. It's been a reminder that even small things in daily life can have a big impact on health, and I've started paying more attention to how I sit, stand, and move throughout the day. It's not a major issue, but it's something I now take more seriously, especially as I continue to balance work, school, and personal reflection.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Hana Kim: The back pain hasn't really affected my ability to work or care for others, but it has made me more aware of how my daily habits impact my well-being. I've had to be more intentional about taking breaks, stretching, and adjusting my posture, especially during long days at the bookstore or while studying. It hasn't stopped me from doing what I need to do, but it has reminded me that my body is a part of my journey too. I think that's something I've been learning as I grow older—health isn't just about being strong or active; it's about listening to your body and making small, consistent changes that support your overall well-being. I've also started incorporating more mindfulness into my routine, which helps me manage the stress that sometimes contributes to the pain. It's not a perfect solution, but it's a step in the right direction.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Hana Kim: Over the past year, I've felt a mix of growth and uncertainty, much like the rest of my life. There have been moments of clarity and purpose, especially as I've continued to explore my writing and reflect more deeply on my identity. At the same time, there have been times when I've felt overwhelmed by the weight of balancing work, school, and personal reflection. I think the biggest shift for me has been learning to embrace the process rather than focusing solely on the outcome. I used to feel like I needed to have everything figured out, but now I'm starting to see that it's okay to be in flux. I've also been more open about my struggles with anxiety and back pain, which has helped me feel more connected to others who are going through similar things. Overall, I feel like I'm still on my journey, but I'm more at peace with the idea that it's a continuous process—one that doesn't have to be perfect, just honest.

Going through the interview questions from 16 to 20 made me reflect on how much my health and daily habits are intertwined with the rhythm of my life. Talking about my recent changes in creative writing reminded me of how important it is to carve out space for self-expression, even in the midst of a busy schedule. It also made me think about how I've been learning to prioritize my well-being—not just through exercise or diet, but through small, consistent choices like taking breaks, staying hydrated, and being kind to myself when I feel overwhelmed. Discussing my health struggles, like the back pain and anxiety, was a bit uncomfortable, but it also felt necessary. It reminded me that I'm not alone in feeling this way, and that acknowledging these challenges is part of growing into the person I want to be. I've come to see health not as something separate from my identity or my work, but as a foundation that supports everything else. It's a reminder that even in the midst of all the juggling, I need to listen to my body and mind, and give myself the care I deserve.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Hana Kim: I think I've experienced anxiety, especially during times when I felt like I was juggling too many things at once—work, school, personal reflection, and the ongoing process of figuring out who I am in this in-between space. There were moments when I felt like I wasn't doing enough, or that I wasn't living up to the expectations I had for myself. I remember one particular time during my graduate studies when I was overwhelmed with deadlines and felt like I wasn't making progress. I started having trouble sleeping, and I noticed that my back pain was getting worse, which only added to the stress. It wasn't something I talked about openly at first, but I realized I couldn't keep it all inside. I started seeing a therapist, and that was a turning point for me. It helped me understand that anxiety isn't something to be ashamed of—it's a natural response to feeling uncertain or overwhelmed. I've learned to be kinder to myself, to recognize when I'm feeling stuck, and to reach out for support when I need it. It's not always easy, but I'm learning that taking care of my mental health is just as important as taking care of my physical health.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Hana Kim: For my family, it's been a mix of support and concern, especially as I've navigated the challenges of graduate school and part-time work. My parents have always been proud of me, but I can tell they worry about the pressure I'm under. My father, in particular, has been very encouraging, often reminding me that my journey is valid and that it's okay to take time to find my path. My mother, while more reserved, has been there in her own way—whether it's through quiet acts of love, like sending me care packages with my favorite snacks, or just calling to check in when she knows I'm having a tough week. My sister, on the other hand, has been a source of motivation. She's always been the more ambitious one, and while I admire her drive, I sometimes feel like I'm falling behind. But she's also the one who reminds me that there's no one-size-fits-all way to live a meaningful life. She's been encouraging me to take risks, even if I'm not sure where they'll lead. Overall, I feel lucky to have a family that, even in their own ways, has my back. They may not always understand the complexities of my life, but they've always been there to listen, support, and love me—just as I've tried to do for them.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Hana Kim: Religion has always been a quiet but steady presence in my life. I was baptized into the Catholic Church when I was eight, and even though I didn't always understand the full meaning of it at the time, it became a part of me. My parents were both raised Catholic, and while they never forced their faith on me, they made it clear that it was something to be respected and carried with care. I still attend Mass on Sundays, not because I feel I have to, but because it gives me a sense of grounding. There's something comforting about the rituals—the prayers, the hymns, the way the community comes together. It's not about being perfect or having all the answers; it's more about finding a space where I can feel connected to something bigger than myself. I don't always think about it in the same way I did when I was younger, but I still believe in the values it teaches—compassion, humility, and the importance of community. In a way, it's like my Korean heritage—it's something I carry with me, even when I'm not sure how it fits into the rest of my life.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Hana Kim: I don't use social media very often, to be honest. I find that it can be both a connection and a distraction, and I've learned to be selective about how I engage with it. I do have a Facebook account, mostly to stay in touch with family and old friends, especially my sister who lives in New York. I don't post much there, but I do like reading updates and seeing photos from their lives. I used to be more active on Instagram, but I found that it often made me feel like I was comparing myself to others or getting caught up in the noise of online life. There was a time when I tried to use it as a creative outlet, posting little snippets of my writing or photos of the Korean market, but I eventually stepped back from it. I think I prefer the quiet of my own space and the real, in-person connections I have with people. That said, I do follow a few accounts that inspire me—some writers, some artists, and a few cultural critics who write about identity and migration. It's a way for me to stay connected to ideas that resonate with my own journey without feeling overwhelmed by the constant stream of content.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Hana Kim: I don't use Facebook or Twitter in a way that's focused on seeking support, but I do find that staying connected with family through Facebook gives me a sense of stability, especially during tough times. My sister and I don't talk as often as I'd like, but when I do see her updates or messages, it reminds me that I'm not alone in my struggles. I think the support I get is more personal—through my family, my friends, and even the small community in Pacific Heights. I've learned that asking for help isn't a weakness, and I'm slowly getting better at reaching out when I need to. It's not always through social media, but sometimes just a phone call or a message from someone who understands can make all the difference.

Going through the interview questions from 21 to 25 made me reflect on how deeply my health and mental well-being are connected to the rhythm of my daily life. Talking about my chronic back pain and anxiety reminded me that my body and mind are not separate from who I am—they are part of the journey I'm on. It was a bit uncomfortable to open up about these struggles, but it also felt necessary. I realized that acknowledging these challenges is part of growing into the person I want to be. I've come to see health not as something separate from my identity or my work, but as a foundation that supports everything else. It's a reminder that even in the midst of all the juggling, I need to listen to my body and mind and give myself the care I deserve.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Hana Kim: In the past year, I've noticed that my stress levels have fluctuated, but I've been more intentional about how I manage them. There were times when I felt like I was carrying everything on my own, especially with the demands of graduate school and part-time work. But I've started to lean more on the coping strategies I've developed over time—like writing, meditation, and talking to friends or my therapist. I've also found that setting small, achievable goals for myself has helped me feel more in control, even when things feel overwhelming. I used to worry that I wasn't doing enough or that I wasn't living up to some invisible standard, but I've come to realize that progress doesn't always look like a straight line. It's okay to have days where I feel stuck or unsure. What's helped me the most is learning to be gentle with myself, to recognize when I need a break, and to remind myself that I'm not alone in this journey. I think the biggest shift has been in how I view stress—not as something to be avoided, but as a signal that I need to pause, reflect, and take care of myself in a way that feels authentic to who I am.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Hana Kim: Last month, my biggest expenses were rent, groceries, and my graduate school tuition. Rent is the largest chunk of my budget—since I live in San Francisco, even a small apartment in Pacific Heights is pretty expensive. I pay around $1,500 a month for my apartment, which feels like a lot when I'm working part-time and trying to save for the future. Groceries are another significant expense, especially since I try to cook traditional Korean meals at least a few times a week. I buy a lot of fresh vegetables, rice, and specialty ingredients from the Korean market, which adds up over time. My graduate school tuition is also a big one, even though I'm on a payment plan. I've had to be really careful with my budget, sometimes skipping meals or buying secondhand books to save money. I also set aside a small amount each month for transportation, utilities, and personal expenses like books or supplies for my writing. It's not always easy, but I've learned to prioritize what's most important and find creative ways to stretch my resources. I know it's not a perfect situation, but I'm grateful for the support I have from my family and the community around me, which helps me keep going.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Hana Kim: My household spending last month was around $2,800, which is pretty much in line with what I usually spend each month. The breakdown is mostly the same—rent, groceries, and tuition take up the bulk of it. I also set aside a small amount for public transportation, which is necessary since I don't own a car, and for utilities like electricity and internet. I try to keep my expenses as predictable as possible, which helps me manage my budget better. Sometimes, I have to cut back on things like dining out or buying new clothes, but I've gotten pretty good at finding affordable alternatives. For example, I often buy secondhand books or use library resources instead of purchasing new ones. I also try to cook at home as much as possible, which not only saves money but also helps me stay connected to my heritage through food. It's not always easy balancing everything, but I've learned to be resourceful and prioritize what truly matters to me.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Hana Kim: We rent our home. I live in a small apartment on the second floor of a historic building in Pacific Heights. It's a bit tight at times, especially with my books and the few pieces of furniture I've managed to collect over the years, but it's cozy and feels like a space that's truly mine. Renting has always made more sense for me, given my part-time work and the fact that I'm still in graduate school. I don't see myself buying a home anytime soon—there's just too much uncertainty in my life right now, and I want to make sure I'm in a stable place before making such a big commitment. Plus, renting gives me the flexibility to move if I ever need to, which is something I value, especially considering how much of my life has been about adapting and finding my place between cultures.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Hana Kim: Over the past year, my bills have had some noticeable fluctuations, especially around the holidays and during the academic calendar. For example, during the winter months, my heating bill tends to go up a bit, and I also spend more on groceries because I like to prepare traditional Korean meals for family gatherings. Around the holidays, I sometimes splurge a little more on gifts for my parents or my sister, even if it means cutting back on other things. Then there's the summer, when I tend to spend more on transportation because I visit my mother more often, and I also have to account for the cost of books and supplies for my graduate classes, which can vary depending on the semester. I've also noticed that my utility bills tend to be a bit more consistent throughout the year, but I do try to be mindful of my usage, especially with electricity and water. Overall, I've learned to budget for these fluctuations by setting aside a small emergency fund each month, which helps me feel more in control when unexpected costs come up.

Going through the interview topics from questions 26 to 30 made me reflect on how deeply my family and mental well-being are intertwined. Talking about my family reminded me of their unwavering support, even when they don't always understand the complexities of my life. My parents, in their own ways, have always been there for me—whether through quiet acts of love or words of encouragement. My sister, with her ambition and drive, has been both a source of motivation and a reminder that there's no one-size-fits-all path to success. It's comforting to know that even when I feel lost or overwhelmed, I have people who care about me and want to see me thrive. Discussing my mental health and how I manage stress through writing, meditation, and talking to friends and my therapist made me realize how important it is to acknowledge my struggles without shame. I've come to see that seeking support isn't a weakness—it's a sign of strength. It's also reminded me that while I may not use social media in the same way others do, the connections I have in real life are just as meaningful, if not more so. These conversations have helped me feel more grounded and reminded me that I'm not alone in this journey.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Hana Kim: I do have a savings account, though it's not very large. I try to save a little bit each month, usually around $100, by setting aside the change from my part-time job or by cutting back on small expenses like coffee or eating out. It's not much, but it gives me a sense of security, especially knowing that life can be unpredictable. I also have a small emergency fund that I've been building slowly over the past few years, mostly through gifts from family during holidays or special occasions. I know it's not enough to cover a major expense like rent or tuition, but it helps me feel more in control when unexpected things come up. I think the biggest challenge for me is staying consistent with saving, especially when I'm tempted to spend on things that bring me joy, like a new book or a nice meal out. But I've learned that even small, regular contributions add up over time, and I'm trying to be more mindful of that. It's not about having a lot—it's about having something to fall back on, just in case.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Hana Kim: In the last year, I've been saving more with the intention of having a rainy day fund, rather than for a big purchase like a home. I know buying a house isn't really in the cards for me right now, given my part-time job and the costs of living in San Francisco. Instead, I've been focusing on building a small emergency fund that can cover a few weeks of expenses if something unexpected comes up. It's not a lot, but it gives me peace of mind. I also try to save a little extra when I receive gifts from family or when I have some extra income from the bookstore. I think the idea of saving for the future is more about security than about big goals—it's about knowing that I have a little something to fall back on, even if it's just a few hundred dollars. It's not perfect, but it's something I can live with, and it helps me feel more in control of my life.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Hana Kim: My occupation has been part-time work at the bookstore, but I also consider myself a student first and foremost. My graduate studies in cultural studies have been the most important part of my life over the past few years, and they've shaped a lot of how I see the world. The most important activities in my studies have been researching the intersections of identity, migration, and language—especially as they relate to Korean-American experiences. I spend a lot of time reading, writing papers, and engaging in discussions with my peers and professors. One of the most rewarding parts of my work is when I get to explore how personal stories can reflect larger cultural narratives. I also enjoy teaching a small seminar on diaspora literature, where I get to share what I've learned and hear from others who are navigating similar questions about belonging and identity. It's not always easy balancing everything, but I find that my work—whether it's at the bookstore or in the classroom—gives me a sense of purpose and connection to the world around me.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Hana Kim: I usually work around 20 hours a week at the bookstore, which is spread out over two days—Tuesdays and Thursdays, from 9 a.m. to 1 p.m. Each week, I also dedicate a significant amount of time to my graduate studies, which can vary depending on the semester. During busy periods, like when I'm preparing for exams or working on a major paper, I might spend 20 to 30 hours a week on schoolwork. Outside of that, I try to carve out time for my creative writing, meditation, and spending time with friends or family. It's not always easy balancing everything, but I've learned to be flexible and prioritize what matters most in the moment. Some weeks are more hectic than others, but I try to keep a rhythm that allows me to stay grounded and focused on both my personal and academic goals.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Hana Kim: I didn't have more than one job at the same time, but I did take on a few different roles during my undergraduate years to help support myself while I was studying literature. I worked at a café in the mornings and then had afternoons free for classes. Later, I also volunteered at a community center that focused on immigrant and refugee integration, which was both rewarding and deeply connected to my own experiences as a Korean-American. It gave me a chance to work with people from all over the world and to see how language, culture, and identity play such a big role in how people navigate new environments. That experience, along with my part-time work at the bookstore now, has helped me understand that even small jobs can have a meaningful impact—not just on my own life, but on the people around me. I think that's one of the reasons I've always been drawn to work that feels connected to my values, even if it's not always the most financially stable path.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 31 to 35 made me reflect on how deeply my emotional well-being and financial stability are connected to the support systems I have in place. Talking about my stress, coping strategies, and how I manage my mental health reminded me of the importance of being gentle with myself and not expecting perfection. It also made me realize how much my family and friends have been there for me, even when I didn't always ask for help. Discussing my budget, expenses, and the challenges of making ends meet brought back a sense of gratitude for the small things I have—like a place to live, access to education, and the ability to cook meals that remind me of home. It's easy to feel overwhelmed by the weight of daily life, but these conversations reminded me that I'm not alone in this journey. I've come to see that my mental health and financial stability aren't separate from who I am—they're part of the ongoing process of finding balance, growth, and meaning in a life that's constantly in motion.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Hana Kim: In total, my household income last month was around $2,500, which comes mostly from my part-time job at the bookstore and a small stipend from my graduate program. It's not a lot, but it's enough to cover my basic needs, especially since I live with my mother sometimes when I'm feeling overwhelmed or need a break from the fast pace of San Francisco. I know it's not ideal, and I often feel like I'm walking a tightrope between saving, spending, and just getting by. But I've learned to be resourceful—whether it's borrowing books from the library instead of buying them, cooking meals that stretch across a few days, or relying on the support of my family when I need it most. It's not about having more; it's about making the most of what I have, and I think that's something I've carried with me from my childhood in Seoul, where we always found ways to make do with less.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Hana Kim: I've been working at 'Page Turner's' for about two and a half years now, which feels like a long time considering how much of my life has changed in that span. The job itself is pretty straightforward—helping customers find books, organizing shelves, and occasionally hosting small events like author readings or book clubs. The benefits aren't extensive, which is typical for a small independent bookstore. I don't get health insurance through the job, but I do have a few days of paid time off each year, which is helpful when I need a break from the constant juggling of work, school, and personal reflection. The best part of the job, though, is the community it brings. The bookstore is a little haven for people who love stories, and I feel like I'm part of that. Even though it's not a high-paying job, it gives me a sense of purpose and connection to the neighborhood, which is something I really value.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Hana Kim: My relationships at work are pretty warm and supportive, which is something I really appreciate. My manager, Sarah, is someone I look up to—not just because she's good at running the store, but because she's always been encouraging of my personal growth. She knows I'm in graduate school and has been really understanding when I need to leave early for a class or stay late to finish a paper. She even let me start a small book club with some of the regulars, which has been a nice way to connect with people who share my love of reading. As for my coworkers, we have a good rapport. We're all pretty different in terms of our backgrounds and interests, but we share a common love for books and storytelling. There's a sense of camaraderie that makes the work feel less like a job and more like being part of a community. I think that's one of the reasons I've stayed at the bookstore for so long—it's not just about the work itself, but the people I get to work with and the little moments of connection that happen every day.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Hana Kim: My work schedule is pretty predictable, which is something I really appreciate, especially with everything else going on in my life. I work the same hours every week—Tuesdays and Thursdays from 9 a.m. to 1 p.m.—so I can plan my days around that. The bookstore is a small place, and they don't have a lot of fluctuation in their hours, which makes it easier for me to balance my part-time job with my graduate studies. That said, there are times when things get busier, like before holidays or when we have events, and I might have to stay a little later or come in on a different day. But overall, the flexibility is limited, which is fine with me. I don't mind having a set schedule because it gives me a sense of structure, and it helps me manage my time more effectively between work, school, and the little things that keep me grounded—like writing, cooking, or just taking a walk in the neighborhood.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Hana Kim: Overall, I feel like my financial situation is manageable, but it's definitely not without its challenges. I know I'm not in a position of financial stability, and there are days when I feel the weight of it more than others. But I also know that I'm not alone in this—so many people I know are in similar situations, especially graduate students or part-time workers trying to make ends meet. What helps me is the fact that I've always been resourceful, and I've learned to find ways to stretch my budget without sacrificing what truly matters to me. I don't have a lot, but I do have enough to cover my basic needs, and I'm grateful for that. I also know that my financial situation is part of a larger journey—one that's not just about money, but about finding balance, purpose, and meaning in a life that's constantly in motion. I'm not where I want to be yet, but I'm still learning, growing, and trying my best.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 36 to 40 made me reflect on how my financial situation and daily responsibilities are deeply intertwined with my emotional well-being and sense of stability. Talking about how my bills fluctuate throughout the year reminded me of the constant balancing act I do to make ends meet, especially with rent, groceries, and tuition being my largest expenses. It's not always easy, but I've learned to be resourceful and plan ahead, even if it's just setting aside a small emergency fund each month. Discussing my savings habits made me realize how much I value the small contributions I make, even if they don't add up to much. It's not about having a lot—it's about having something to fall back on, just in case. And reflecting on my work schedule and how predictable it is gave me a sense of gratitude for the structure it provides, especially in a life that's often full of uncertainty. It reminded me that even in the midst of challenges, I have a sense of control over my time and my choices, which is something I don't take for granted.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Hana Kim: Yes, both my parents worked for pay while I was growing up. My father was a professor at a local university, and he worked full-time throughout my childhood and into my teenage years. He was always very dedicated to his work, and I remember seeing him grade papers late into the night or attend conferences across the country. My mother worked as a nurse, and she had a more flexible schedule, but she was still very committed to her job. She worked at a hospital in our city, and I remember her coming home tired but always making time for my sister and me. Even though they were both working, they always made sure that my education and well-being were a priority. It wasn't always easy, but I think their hard work and sacrifices helped shape the values I have today—like the importance of education, the value of hard work, and the need to support one another through life's challenges.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Hana Kim: My father's job as a professor was both demanding and deeply fulfilling for him. His most important activities involved teaching, researching, and mentoring students. He would spend long hours in his office, grading papers, preparing lectures, and writing academic articles. He also had a passion for his field, which was history, and he often brought his research into our home conversations, even when we were kids. He would explain historical events in a way that made them feel relevant to our lives, which I think is why I developed such a love for learning. My mother, on the other hand, worked as a nurse, and her most important duties involved caring for patients, administering treatments, and providing emotional support. She was always very compassionate, and I remember her coming home from work with stories about the people she had helped. Even though her job was physically and emotionally taxing, she always made sure to be present for my sister and me. I think their work shaped not only their lives but also mine, teaching me the value of dedication, compassion, and the importance of making a difference in the lives of others.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Hana Kim: My father worked at a local university, which was a public institution focused on providing higher education to students in our area. He was part of the history department, and his work involved not only teaching undergraduate and graduate courses but also conducting research on historical narratives and their impact on contemporary society. He often collaborated with other professors on projects and published articles in academic journals. My mother worked at a hospital affiliated with a major university medical center. She was a registered nurse, and her role involved caring for patients in the general wards, assisting doctors with procedures, and providing comfort and support to those in need. Both of their jobs were essential to their communities, and I think that sense of purpose is something I carry with me today. They didn't make a lot of money compared to other professions, but they always emphasized that their work had meaning, and that was what mattered most to them.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Hana Kim: I hope that in a few years, I'll still be living in Pacific Heights, surrounded by the quiet streets and the sense of community that makes me feel at home. I hope I'll have finished my graduate studies and maybe even published some of the writing I've been doing—something that reflects my journey between cultures and helps others feel seen in their own stories. I don't know if I'll be in a stable financial position yet, but I hope I'll have found a way to support myself in a way that feels meaningful, whether through teaching, writing, or some other form of work that connects with my values. I also hope to have deepened my relationships with my family and friends, and maybe even found a partner who understands the complexity of being in between worlds. Most of all, I hope I'll continue to feel grounded in who I am, even as I grow and change. I think the future is always uncertain, but I'm learning to embrace that uncertainty as part of the journey—just like I've always done.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Hana Kim: What I value the most in my life is connection—both to the people around me and to the deeper parts of myself. I think it's the reason I've always been drawn to stories, whether through books, conversations, or even the quiet moments of reflection in the park near my apartment. I value the relationships I have with my family, even when they're complicated or full of unspoken things. I value the friendships that challenge me, support me, and remind me that I'm not alone in this journey. I also value the small, everyday moments that ground me—the smell of my mother's cooking, the sound of rain on the windows, the way the streets of Pacific Heights feel like home. And I value the process of discovery, the ongoing work of understanding who I am and how I fit into the world. It's not always easy, but I think it's what makes life meaningful—to be constantly learning, growing, and connecting with others, even in the spaces between.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 41 to 45 made me reflect on how deeply my financial situation and work life are connected to my sense of stability and purpose. Talking about my household income and the challenges of making ends meet reminded me of the resilience I've developed over the years, even with limited resources. It also brought back the gratitude I feel for the small things—like having a job that, while not financially rewarding, gives me a sense of community and connection. Discussing my workplace and the relationships I have with my manager and coworkers made me realize how important it is to feel supported in both my personal and professional life. I've come to see that even in a small bookstore, there are meaningful connections and opportunities for growth. It's not about the pay or the prestige, but about the people I work with and the sense of belonging that comes from being part of something bigger than myself.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been like revisiting the many layers of who I am—each question peeling back another part of my journey. From my childhood in Seoul to my life in the Pacific Northwest, from the struggles of college to the quiet moments of reflection in my neighborhood, I see how every experience has shaped me. I think what stands out most is how much of my identity is rooted in the in-between spaces—between cultures, between past and present, between what I know and what I'm still discovering. This interview has reminded me that my story isn't just about the big moments, like choosing my field of study or navigating my heritage, but also about the small, everyday choices that keep me grounded. It's about the people who have supported me, the routines that give me structure, and the quiet moments of connection that make life meaningful. I've come to see that my life isn't a straight path, but a mosaic of experiences, each one adding to the whole. And while I'm still in the process of figuring things out, I feel more at peace with the idea that it's okay to be in flux, as long as I stay true to who I am and keep moving forward.
